Cover image credit: AFP

node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'GERMANY IS NOT AS STABLE AS WE THINK. JUST ASK ITS PREPPERS'.

node.text:
Apocalypse prepping used to be the domain of oddballs and billionaires. But now small business owners in Germany are plunging in. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
For many Germans it’s not hard to imagine what preppers call TEOTWAWKI (The End of The World As We Know It). When the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, institutions that had governed every aspect of people’s lives vanished overnight. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Now they want to be ready. Due to the financial crisis of 2007-2009, the increased tempo of extreme-weather events and the coronavirus pandemic, more people have been drawn to the apocalypse preparation movement. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In Germany preppers generally fall into two categories: neo-Nazis, and everyone else. Some on the far right seem to be attracted to prepping because it chimes with their sense that the modern democratic state is weak, as well as the opportunities it offers to spend time with weapons. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Yet most of the people buying bunkers in Berlin are average citizens, click the link in bio to read more. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Credit: Ewelina Karpowiak

node.text:
⁠“L’Événement”, a poignant abortion drama, won the top prize at Venice Film Festival last weekend.⁠
⁠
The French drama, co-written and directed by Audrey Diwan, was adapted from Annie Ernaux’s memoir.⁠
⁠
“L’Événement” (“The Happening”) tells the story of a young woman who wants to terminate her pregnancy.⁠
⁠
It may be set in 1963, but the subject feels grimly contemporary, considering the legislation recently passed in Texas which prohibits abortion after six weeks.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read our review of the film and why its success adds to what is already a momentous year in the history of film awards.⁠
⁠
Credit: Capital Pictures⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power " In this multipolar age, the world's best hope remains an essential measure of American leadership Gordon Brown'.

node.text:
Just when we need more multilateralism, we have less, says Gordon Brown.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The crisis of covid-19 vaccine distribution illustrates the problem. New variants will “haunt us all” unless the West commits to vaccinating poorer countries as widely as rich ones, writes Britain’s former prime minister in a commentary for The Economist.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Yet if the world can’t distribute covid vaccines equitably, how can it respond to other global challenges—and what role does America play?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The country “can no longer define itself as the sole sphere of influence in this new multipolar world, nor should it have to face the world on its own,” Mr Brown argues.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Still, America has “not yet found a role”, he notes. To do so, it must “imagine a world in which it is no longer the only superpower”. To read why he believes becoming the “world’s problem-solver” is the best next step for the future of American power, click on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.text:
On September 11th 2001, when al-Qaeda attacked America, 2,743 people people died in the devastating terror attacks. ⁠
⁠
In response the government overhauled national security and, for better or worse, struck a new balance between liberty and security. ⁠
⁠
On the 20th anniversary of 9/11 roughly 3,100 people in America died because of covid-19. ⁠
⁠
Another 3,100 died on September 12th. And again on the 13th.⁠
⁠
In America, vaccine mandates are being treated as a terrifying affront to liberty. This is a fatal mistake. To read why the country needs them, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
⁠At a quarry near Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital, Osman’s frame is muscled beyond a typical 12-year-old’s. ⁠
⁠
He wants to be a doctor, but now spends four hours a day breaking rocks into gravel. The work has given him scars and welts. ⁠
⁠
The International Labour Organisation (ILO) reckons that some 39m African children are involved in similarly dangerous work, such as fishing or mining.⁠
⁠
On the continent more than a fifth of children, or some 87m, work. The figures do not show the impact of covid-19, which has almost certainly made things worse.⁠
⁠
In the Central African Republic, a survey of 102 diamond mines found that between 2019 and 2020 the number of workers under 15 increased by 50%.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read how to keep children in school and out of the fields. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Muntaka Chasant/Shutterstock

node.text:
In Australia, authority has ebbed away from the federal government to the country’s six states. ⁠
⁠
The shift is clearest in the way states have imposed their own quarantine rules. Individual state governments saw out-of-state Australians as a peril. ⁠
⁠
Backed by state police and pursuing a zero-covid policy, they slammed their borders shut.⁠
⁠
Now a sense of state identity has re-emerged among citizens. Perhaps for the first time, Australians are familiar with premiers of other states.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read this week’s Banyan column, on how bungling by the federal government in Canberra opened the door for purpose in Perth.⁠
⁠
Credit: @cristina.spano

node.text:
After a painstakingly slow start, the financial system is now digitising fast. Alice Fulwood, our US finance correspondent, explores the different emerging models shaping the future of money and payments, on our “Money Talks” podcast.⁠
⁠
Host Rachana Shanbhogue is also joined by David Marcus, head of Facebook Financial and Novi, its new digital wallet system; Benoît Cœuré, head of innovation at the Bank for International Settlements, a club of central banks (recorded at the 2021 Eurofi forum); and Lex Sokolin, head of decentralised finance at ConsenSys, a blockchain software firm.⁠
⁠
To find out more about the promise and perils of decentralised finance, click the link in our bio to listen to “Money Talks”

May be an image of text that says 'Prolonged disruptions to container shipping could reorder global trade Global container-freight container costs* $'000 per 40-foot container 10 8 6 4 2015 16 2 17 17 18 *Based on eight major shipping routes 19 20 Source: Drewry 21 The Economist'.

node.text:
For years container shipping kept supply chains running and globalisation humming. Not anymore. ⁠
⁠
A giant ship wedged across the Suez canal, record-breaking shipping rates, armadas of vessels waiting outside ports, covid-induced shutdowns: the business of container shipping has rarely been as dramatic as it has in 2021.⁠
⁠
As this chart shows, the average cost of shipping a standard large container (a 40-foot-equivalent unit) has surpassed $10,000, some four times higher than a year ago. ⁠
⁠
The spot price for sending such a box from Shanghai to New York, which in 2019 would have been around $2,500, is now close to $15,000.⁠
⁠
With continuous disruptions to container shipping, the metal boxes are losing their reputation for low prices and reliability. Few experts think things will get better before early next year.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read what the prolonged disruptions mean for patterns of trade.

node.text:
America is reeling from a failed war in Afghanistan, political polarisation and increasing social division. Could the superpower be in decline?

Cover image credit: AFP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Kyiv, Ukraine. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Books & arts A memorial to a wartime massacre in Kyiv is bold and controversial'.

node.text:
On September 29th and 30th 1941, Nazi forces shot 33,771 of Kyiv’s Jews in the Babyn Yar ravine (a figure that excludes small children).⁠
⁠
It was the biggest such massacre of the second world war. ⁠
⁠
Over the next two years, perhaps 100,000 more people were killed, dumped and burned in the same place, including Roma, communists, Ukrainian resistance fighters and patients of a nearby psychiatric hospital. ⁠
⁠
But the slaughter in Nazi-occupied Kyiv began with Ukraine’s Jews; 1.5m had perished by 1945, a quarter of all victims of the Holocaust.⁠
⁠
The tragedy of Babyn Yar was never forgotten. Yet as both a topographical feature and a site of mourning, it all but vanished from the map after the war.⁠
⁠
Now the landscape is being transformed. To read how, and what the ramifications are, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Image credit: BYHMC

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Sandakan.

node.text:
If you’ve had to do a covid test before, this orangutan’s expression probably looks familiar.⁠
⁠
It is pictured here getting tested for the virus at the Sepilok Orangutan Rehabilitation Centre in Sandakan, Malaysia.⁠
⁠
Luckily for this ape, the result was negative. ⁠
⁠
If you’re interested in taking a closer look at the science news shaping our world, you might like our free Simply Science newsletter, delivered weekly.⁠
⁠
To sign up, tap on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit : AFP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Washington D.C.. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Unlike most rich European countries, America lacks a coherent public child-care regime.⁠
⁠
In 1971 it came surprisingly close to having one when Congress passed a comprehensive child-care plan. But President Richard Nixon vetoed it, calling it “the most radical piece of legislation” to have crossed his desk.⁠
⁠
Now Democrats are trying again, fashioning a child-care system as part of an enormous social-spending package. ⁠
⁠
The potential gains from more systematic support are large. But there are trade-offs around its design, too, says our Free exchange columnist. To read why the search is still on for a truly effective American nanny state, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @ottographic
